qas.question: What took the place of the German DIN 4512 system?
How is sensitivity shown in the ISO systems?

answers.text: in linear and logarithmic form as "ISO 100/21°"

qas.question: What standards did the DIN begin to use?
When were the ISO standards first adopted?
When were the last ISO standards adopted?
What did the German DIN 4512 supersede?
What German system wrote in a linear and logarithmic form?
When did the ISO adopt the DIN standards?
When did DIN 4512-5:1990-11 replace DIN ISO 5800:1998-06?

context: On an international level the German <b6_0>DIN 4512<b6_0/> system has been effectively superseded <a3_0>in the <b8_0>1980s<b8_0/><a3_0/> by <a0_0><b5_0>ISO 6:1974, ISO 2240:1982, and ISO 5800:1979<b5_0/><a0_0/> where the same sensitivity is written <a1_0>in linear and logarithmic form as "ISO 100/21°"<a1_0/> (now again with degree symbol). These <a2_0><b7_0>ISO<b7_0/> standards<a2_0/> were subsequently adopted by DIN as well. Finally, the latest DIN 4512 revisions were replaced by corresponding ISO standards, DIN 4512-1:1993-05 by DIN ISO 6:1996-02 in September 2000, DIN 4512-4:1985-08 by DIN ISO 2240:1998-06 and DIN 4512-5:1990-11 by DIN ISO 5800:1998-06 both in <a4_0><b9_0>July 2002<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
